review:
I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right handâ€”the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bedâ€”the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11208, 'playtime_forever': 335, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 335, 'last_played': 1681987095}
review:
Fallen is a 2D retro platformer and unabashed ripoff of the highly successful puzzle platformer, Limbo, right down to the dark foreground/coloured background theme distinctive of the game (and that's been ripped off by so many "amateur" hacks since, because it's easy to do, and "amateur" developers are lazy).  Of course this one is terrible, and it's pretty close to being an asset flip.  It was slapped together with some sprites and tiles that were presumably ripped off the internet somewhere, and bolted together with the code-free point-and-click ClickTeam Fusion construction kit... no actual game development took place on this train wreck. 

From a technical perspective, the game doesn't meet basic minimum requirements that most PC gamers expect as standard.

There's no options to change the resolution for the game or customise the graphics settings.  There's no way for gamers to ensure this is running at the native resolution of their displays... there's no guarantee this game will look right on any PC as a result of this hamfisted design decision.  There's no way for gamers to try improve the low quality graphics. 

The game features simple, cartoony 2D graphics, of the type you normally expect to see in low effort mobile apps.  3D graphics programming does require a degree of skill and competence and unfortunately not all developers have the budget or talent to deliver this, despite 3D graphics cards hitting the mainstream in the 1990's.  Considering this is being evaluated as a PC game, having the graphics phoned in like this isn't going to result in a high quality, visually impressive game that PC gamers are used to seeing.

The controls can't be customised, which will be an annoyance for many, but it can also render the game unplayable for differently-abled gamers.

Some of the defects in the game can be attributed to the choice of using the Clickteam Fusion construction kit - the "No-Code" construction kit that "Anyone can make games with!!".  Including, you know, people who aren't game developers.  Which is a problem.  This is a very poor quality toolset sometimes used by amateur developers as it's free (so they don't have to pay for GameMaker Studio) and doesn't require advanced game development skills, but unfortunately has very limited capabilities (it's arguably worse than GameMaker Studio).  Just as you can't make a silk purse out of a sows ear, you can't make a great video game if you use a terrible engine.

These technical defects push this game below acceptable standards for any modern PC game.

You don't have to take my word about how bad the game is, we can measure the interest in a game by how much people bothered to play it.  Fallen has achievements, and they show us a very clear picture that the game absolutely failed to capture any interest from gamers.  The most commonly and easily attained achievement is for "meeting a ghost" (something that happens in the first few minutes of the game), but less than 3 percent of players bothered to get that far before uninstalling the game.  That's a tiny, tiny proportion of gamers who even bothered with this.  Ouch.

Reviewing SteamDB to check how popular this game was with players reveals a surprise... there's a very healthy spike in player counts for the game.  But this isn't consistent with the achievement stats, that show less than 3 percent of players bothered playing the game for any reasonable amount of time.  How is it possible for this game to have so many concurrent players who weren't even playing the game?  Trading cards.  Players will use card idling software to collect the cards and sell them, but this won't trigger any achievements in-game.  That tells us people only really bought this game for trading cards, and that's a damning indictment of the woeful quality.  A closer look at the numbers shows the game just has a couple of players every week running up the game and idling it for cards, then deleting it.  We must ask how it benefits gamers for there to be so many games like this, with no merit as a serious game, that only generate sales from people idling and selling the trading cards.

Fallen is relatively cheap at $2 USD, but it's not worth it. Given the defects and quality issues with the game, coupled with the unrealistic price, this is impossible to recommend.

review: Absolutely rubbish platformer. You run around these similar looking dark levels with random figures flying around hitting switches without much of a story. The main problem is the one thing that should be good, the platforming. You run around these big open levels with long platforms and environments to reach, with a ton of backtracking, but your guy walks like he's stuck in quicksand. Theres no run option, and it was so bad I thought i was getting FPS drop, which the computer read at 25 fps, but when I'd shoot or anything else would occur it would be normal so it was clear they just made it that way to take longer. Also when you jump its super slow and u float up in the air for 5s like you're a balloon, which is annoying to wait for your guy to come down. Also the double jump is horribly designed and if you press it twice you don't get high, you have to time it perfectly and jump at the exact height of the second jump which takes a while and is hard to judge due to how floaty the jumping is. If you don't time it perfect, which doesn't matter in most good platformers, you can't make most of the desired jumps. I died a couple times and gave up since i dreaded running back so slowly through the same parts backtracking while going slower than most turtles, which could have been easily avoided. 3.5/10.

review:
Preview negative review:

Ok, I played until the 4th level, mainly because I love platformers.

The good:

- It's a platformer.
- It has a kind of interesting story.
- The music sets a good atmosphere (for a while)

The bad:

- You can't skip dialogs or "cut-scenes" (extremely frustrating if you are repeating a level because you died)
- There are some platforms that are unnecessarily slow, and if you fall you have to wait a lot to get back in.
- The buy mechanic is interesting game-wise, but at the same time it feels lazy, because who are you buying the things from. At the beginning it just says: Press S to buy. The gems have also no story.
- The names are way too generic and not very well thought out. Demon King. Charlie. Also *SPOILER AHEAD* not very much emotion when you find your kid.
- Too much backtracking when you light on a switch.
- Hit box of the bats is annoying.
- Nothing new towards the course of the first 4 levels.
- The ghosts are very annoying to deal with, they are too fast and out of nowhere sometimes.
- I got to the 4th level, died, run out of green gems, tried it again, couldn't skip dialogs, died again, quit. Not because I quit games (I got almost of the achievements in super meat boy and dark souls 1), but because it wasn't much fun.
- Enemies can damage you even if you kill them before the visually touch you.
- There's a glitch where you just slide.
- The world is unnecessarily dark and sometimes you can't distinguish enemies or things that hurt.
- Dialogs are not very well written, grammar wise.

I would love to play a polished version of this game. Don't recommend it right now for that price.

Updated Review:

I have changed my review from negative to positive because the dev has been making good updates and decided not to abandon the game.

Collision problems are mostly solved, dialog scenes are now skippable, movement feels smother, soundtracks are good, story is kind of interesting once you beat the game, achievementes are now attainable and not frustrating impossible levels (Death race).

Overall a nice little platformer that has a new mechanic (buying bullets and extra lifes in game).
